Civil Rights attorney Lynne Stewart was sentenced today to 28 months in prison.
She had been facing up to 30 years.
Stewart was convicted in 2005 of aiding terrorists by allowing her client, the blind Sheik Omar Abdel-Rahman, to communicate with a reporter from prison.
NPR's Margot Adler joins us now from outside the courthouse in New York.
And, Margot, what was the reaction outside the courthouse after the judge issued that sentence?
Well, there were about several hundred of her supporters there.
And when they heard that Lynne Stewart had received 28 months instead of 30 years, there was incredible relief, chanting, applause.
I think the relief was palpable.
Did you hear anything from Lynne Stewart herself?
Yes.
She came out with her husband, Ralph Pointer, with three of her 14 grandchildren.
She was handed a bouquet of roses.
And she basically said no one looks forward to two years in jail.
But as my clients have said - and remember she has a history of defending poor and unpopular clients - as my clients have said, I can do that standing on my head.
We won a great victory over an overreaching government.
I want you to remind us what Sheik Oman Abdel-Rahman did, who he is and what Lynne Stewart did to help him communicate from jail.
He is an Egyptian cleric who was convicted in 1995 of a foiled plot to bomb New York City monuments.
Stewart was his lawyer in the case.
But her real problem started after that, when she was essentially his lawyer and he was in jail and she was advocating for prison conditions.
And in the course of that, she violated Special Administrative Measures, known at SAMs, which basically forbid that the sheik communicate with his followers or with the media.
And she gave a statement to Reuters that basically said that the sheik no longer supported the cease-fire between his group, the Islamic group, and the Egyptian government.
Now I understand that you and other reporters could not get into the courtroom today.
What do you know about what the judge said at sentencing?
Well, what we heard from the few reporters that got in, and the Washington Post and CNN and Daily News, you know, didn't get in, the judge was really interesting.
He basically said he could not give the sentence the government wanted because of Stewart's extraordinary work.
That the government had asked for 30 years.
Judge Koeltl said the sentence warrants a substantial downward variant because of her personal characteristics.
He mentioned her age - 67 - he cancer, her 30 years of defending poor and unpopular clients, that she never used her career for personal gain, that she was financially destitute.

Then he talked about the crime, and he said that yes, it was an incredibly serious crime abusing her position as a lawyer to smuggle communications for her client, releasing potentially lethal public statements, actions way beyond zealous advocacy, but the crimes do not wipe out 30 years of service.
And therefore he was going to give her 28 months.
And what did the prosecutor say about that.
We did not hear.
It's very, very, you know, you never hear from the prosecution.
They did not come out and did not talk with the press.
But they clearly were deeply disappointed.
Again, the news today from the court in New York City is a 28 month sentence for civil rights lawyer Lynne Stewart.
Margot Adler, thank you very much.
You're welcome.

Washington Mutual was another casualty of the mortgage downturn.
It did a lot of mortgage lending especially in California and Florida, which, as you probably know, are sort of ground zero in the foreclosure crisis.

The Office of Thrift Supervision, which regulates the banks, said it lost than $6 billion in the last three quarters, and that was bad enough, but then in the past week or 10 days or so, something else had happened.

There's been so much turmoil on Wall Street that customers have been pulling money out of the bank, about $16 billion since, I think, September 15th, which is about nine percent of Washington Mutual's total deposits, as of June 30th.
So, the government figured, you know, it had to step in, so that's what it did.
Washington Mutual, we should keep in mind, is a retail bank.
It has customers that have deposits.
What happens to them?
Well, the government says it's reopening today as usual.
It will just have new owners.
They say it will be a seamless transition.
Customers won't even know anything is different, and because the bank is being purchased by JPMorgan Chase, the customers' deposits will be protected.
The regulators are just trying to do what they always do in situations like this, which is just convince people things are normal, so there isn't a run on the bank.
Why does JPMorgan Chase step in on this one?
Why take over a troubled bank like this one?
Well, the regulators were pressuring some of the big banks to step in, meeting with them recently, getting them to try to do a big deal.
JPMorgan Chase was the one that stepped forward.
They're the ones, you may remember, that bought Bear Stearns last March.
They are in a pretty good position right now for a bank, and they can go around shopping for deals, and Washington Mutual I guess they saw as a good deal.
It's got 2200 branches.
A lot of them are on the West Coast.
JPMorgan Chase doesn't have a lot of branches on the West Coast.
So, they thought it was a good fit, and it's going to pay about $2 billion.
Of course, it's also got to take on a lot Washington Mutual's questionable mortgage securities, some of its bad debts, but they obviously think they can make the deal work.
